{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3135815,"name":"G3 6740","username":"G3_6740","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/3d9bf3/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-29T09:46:00.899Z","cooked":"

If I have a mechanism that needs to be opened, yet I don’t want to put a motor on it, what would work the best? ( It’s on a door hinge )

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-01-29T09:46:00.899Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":298,"readers_count":297,"score":119.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":425020,"topic_slug":"a-primitive-mechanism","display_username":"G3 6740","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29450,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/a-primitive-mechanism/425020/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3135824,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2023-01-29T12:50:36.827Z","cooked":"

That all depends on what you want the mechanism to do. If you need it to have some force behind the opening (or closing) and it only needs to go to two positions (open and closed) then the answer is a pneumatic cylinder. If you need more subtle control and it doesn’t require much force, then a servo may do the trick. If you only need it to open once then the driving force can be a spring (constant force, coil, whatever, depending on application) that is constrained and then released (again, probably by a pneumatic cylinder or servo, but a much smaller one.) That’s just off the top of my head, not knowing what you’re trying to do or how the mechanism is otherwise constructed. If you’d give us some details, many folks here could give you a more refined and better idea of solutions to your problem.

I just need it to push something that sits on an axis

Strategic:

If you’d give us some details, many folks here could give you a more refined and better idea of solutions to your problem.

@Strategic’s comment covers a variety of options from a high level. You likely won’t get a better answer without providing more details. How big of a mechanism is it? How much force does it need to apply? What’s the range of motion?

CAD file (or screenshot of it at least) would go a long way here, but we’d need some numbers as well.
